The acting was top notch and strict adherence to the actual events is admirable. The only thing I would have liked to see more of was the boys while waiting to be rescued.

True story. A group of Thai kids go caving with their football coach and get trapped by the monsoon rains. No stone is left unturned in the seemingly impossible task of rescuing the party including bringing in rescue divers from across the globe, including Vigo Mortensen, Colin Farrell and Joel Edgerton.The first half is a little slow and the second, where the ingenious rescue attempt is made, is full of suspense and claustrophobia in the flooded tight fitting caves. But in fairness, director Ron Howard has chosen to recreate this end to end story as accurately, I guess with a touch of dramatic license, as he can. As such, there will be changes in pace as there will have been at the time, sometimes focussing on family angst, operational constraints, local politics and our heroes doing their thing. That Howard has played it straight without melodrama and daft speeches, is to his credit. This isn't the most exciting film ever made, but it has its moments and is certainly to the credit of the divers involved in the rescue operation, played with understated aplomb by the 3 leads.

reviews.review_title: I was so ready to be disappointed after the incredible national geographic documentary. But this is actually on par because of the amazing amount of respect that runs through
reviews.content: The national geographic documentary about this miracle event was so good I was so ready to be disappointed by this and thought it would be a cheap Hollywood attempt at making money out of such an emotional but ultimately inspiring real life event. I was so pleased to be wrong. It is a long film but it never drags. The swimming through the cave shots get a bit repetitive and were not done as well as National Geographic managed to do them - they were too dark and obscured. But everything about this felt deeply respectful to authenticity, the facts of the event, the people involved, the victims, etc. Colin Farrell and Viggo Mortensen are absolutely brilliant in their attempts to accurately portray the mannerisms and personalities of the normal unremarkable but remarkable British heroes who led the expedition. Colin Farrell the actor completely disappeared, you could not discern any of him in his voice or his mannerisms. And this was without wearing any makeup or costume. Absolutely outstanding. Viggo was equally good though not quite as impressive. But the energy they both carried themselves with was one of utter respect for the real life heroes they were portraying. And this imbued out to all of the production. There was no hollywood sensationalism. Just respect. And that was deeply felt. And because of that all the raw emotion of the ordeal was allowed to shine through organically. One of the most emotional hollywood films I have seen in sometime, on par with the documentary. This is not to be underestimated. We live in a crazy sensationalist world where everything is completely overblown and catastrophised because we are so difficult to shock and surprise these days because with the worst and best of humanity available everyday at our fingertips on the internet we think we have seen it all. So to take this approach was very brave and extremely refreshing and was what Hollywood and audiences have drastically been missing. Hopefully this will inspire more films, real and fiction, to a higher form of authenticity for the future. We so badly need it.

This is a rare event; a biographical film that still feels authentic and riveting despite its predictability.The cinematography is dirty, grimy, and claustrophobic, truly forcing the grim settings of the caves upon you. Even though I always knew what was going to happen, I still tensed up whenever something went wrong during the rescue procedures.The production design, sets, and props are all so well-crafted and well-utilised. They're huge and they appear messy and worn-down, never shying away from the depths that the real-world volunteers put themselves in to do what needed to be done.At 2 1/2 hours long, I was surprised at how well-paced the story felt. Sometimes there are some events that can feel shoehorned in out of necessity, but for the most part every sequence feels important and advances the direction situation.Like a lot of biographical films of this nature, this one does juggle a lot of characters, and at times more than it can feasibly handle. And the ending comes across as somewhat anticlimactic.But given the scale of the task that was taken on by these filmmakers, it's monumentally impressive how well-balanced everything is.

reviews.review_title: Where did this movie come from
reviews.content: Flying in under the radar with apparently zero promotional budget from Amazon, Ron Howard delivers a gripping drama. Very efficient, methodical story sticks to the events of the rescue with virtually no backstory other than the fact Colin Farrell's character has a young son. Good balance with the Thai characters so the story doesn't devolve into a white savior fable.

In 2018, the harrowing rescue of the soccer team trapped in the Tham Luang cave was all over the news. Four years later, this dramatic retelling of those 18 days has finally hit the big screen (well, at least on Amazon Prime). While the film does a great job of showing the inside view of the true events, there is not much more substance to it. The film does have some tense moments that are truly anxiety-inducing, but there is never a moment where the full gravity of the situation is felt.The story is awe-inspiring. Ron Howard is a great director. Viggo Mortensen, Colin Farrell and Joel Edgerton are great actors. Taking all that into account, "Thirteen Lives" is a good movie. The screenplay stuck to the source material and illustrated the events that took place. Unfortunately, there isn't much more depth to it. Simply put, "Thirteen Lives" is best described as a no-nonsense film.Best Character: Dr. Harry
Best Quote: "Fear is created in our minds." - The Coach
Best Scene: The first discovery.

reviews.review_title: Escapes the trap of the usual Hollywood treatment
reviews.content: I was tentatively hopeful when starting to watch this film, since the director has done excellent work before - and I was happy to find my hopes answered: Thirteen Lives is a great film about the tragic event and does not fall into the usual trap of Hollywood treatment (inserting unnecessary and fake human drama or stories). The boys are just human beings and we care for them for that reason - not because we have been explicitly told about their future hopes and dreams and then pointedly explained to that those dreams are in peril now. Everyone understands that already.

This is a review based solely on the movie. I have not watched the documentary, though I've heard it's also incredible.A truly incredible story of perseverance, strength, patience, and skill. Ron Howard tells it straight forward with no nonsense. Not many exaggerations are needed with a story like this, it has more than enough tense moments on its own. This very well may be my favourite film of Howard's in a long career of many quality films.It also doesn't hurt when you have some of my favourite, and in my opinion, extremely gifted actors in Viggo, Colin, and Joel. All three were phenomenal, but especially the first two.The film did a great job at showing all the contributing parties, the world coming together, the resilience of the boys, and the very concerned parents. The skill and mindset of those cave divers is something else. The SEALs contribution and sacrifice cannot be commended enough.Hearing the World Cup playing at various moments was also a good touch. It was a reminder as to how recent this was.

Excellent reenactment of the Tham Luang cave rescue in Thailand. I watched the documentary a few months ago and the movie is very accurate.Very well directed by Ron Howard, keeping schmaltz to a minimum and going straight to the point without the usual time wasting in the beginning.My only complaint is that it's juat too long. It's 2.5 hours (including 10 min of end credits) and shouldn't have been more than 105 min. The last 30-45 min are just stretching.Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: A thrilling, suspenseful and heartfelt film that restores your faith in humanity
reviews.content: Roger Ebert once said that it wasn't the sad parts in movies that made him cry, it was seeing people doing selfless, kind acts. I watched the new Ron Howard Prime Video film, "Thirteen Lives" and I must confess I got misty. You'll probably recall the 2018 incident in Thailand when 12 boys and their soccer coach got trapped in a huge cave that flooded. Help came from all over the world - more than 5000 pitched in to this difficult rescue effort.For this movie, the cave's interiors and miles of flooded passageways were recreated on a set. Could have fooled me though. As someone who has been spelunking, I can say that Howard captured the claustrophobic atmosphere perfectly. After taking basic scuba training during role prep, Viggo Mortensen advocated for his fellow actors and won the "privilege" of doing all their own diving scenes. Very impressive.In an interesting script choice, the viewer is largely given the perspective of the rescuers. After we see the kids and their coach disappear into the cave, the point of view switches to the parents who first sound the alarm to authorities. Unexpected pre-monsoon rains make the situation critical. The kids came straight from soccer practice and are not equipped to survive such an ordeal.Then the focus shifts to the rescuers as the agonized parents look on. Watching the rescue team grow and come up with a plan, then execute it is the heart of the film. This is largely because of the kindness of countless strangers - many of whom simply showed up at the site and asked to help. I believe the movie accurately portrays the mental and physical perils involved. The diving scenes are harrowing and not for the claustrophobic. Although the actors were OK, two of the real life rescuers died as a result of their efforts.I found Thirteen Lives a thrilling, suspenseful, and heartwarming film. I'd like to think that we still live in a world where such kindness is still possible. Highly recommended.

reviews.review_title: I found my thrill, on Blueberry Hill. Too bad it was a day late and a dollar short.
reviews.content: I may have not minded as much if the 147 min runtime was chopped down to around 90-100 mins, but with the slow pacing, this was just too long and dragged out.Sure, excellent cinematography, and amazing casting and performances, but nothing new or different from the docu-film The Rescue, which was just as well shot, and felt more authentic with the actual real-life rescuers and kids - and only 107 mins long.I guess if you haven't seen the docu-film, you may enjoy this one more if you can sit through repetitive and slow dive scenes, and dull, drab, emotionless and uninspiring story-telling, with only Hollywood-styled impressive camera-work to look forward to. Howard's Blueberry Hill's thrill was 301 days too late and $55M too much.

Ron Howard achieves precisely what he wanted to by not exaggerating anything or glamorising the relief effort. The performances are perfect for their roles and everyone seems so real. The scale of the effort is made clear and the camera work is claustrophobic. This would be a much better film to me if I didn't already know what happens.

Long movie but reels you in quickly and holds you tight. This movie effectively recreates the tension while the world held its breath praying for the rescue of those boys. No need to go into more details. This movie is excellent. Has to be Ron Howard's finest achievement to date.

reviews.review_title: Best movie seen on amazon prime.
reviews.content: I love how they made this movie. It is really good on how the story they made on the rescue mission in surviving the people who are in the cave and getting out. I give 10/10 For all the people and makers of the film. Nice one.

reviews.review_title: The true tale of extreme heroism
reviews.content: One Hollywood's best directors, Ron Howard, has engaged three of the world's best actors, Viggo Mortensen, Colin Farrell & Joel Edgerton to tell the true story of the "world's greatest rescue." In June 2018, a 12-person Thai soccer team of young men (after their ordeal, even the youngest deserve to be called men) plus their coach go to explore a local cave after practice. Then monsoon season begins earlier than usual, and they're all trapped deep within a chamber by the ensuing severe flooding. Late that night, their parents realize what's happened and the "authorities" are called in. Unfortunately, the best "cave rescue divers" in the world (who even knew that was a thing?) from the UK arrived more than a week later, when some of the community had already begun to lose hope. After finally reaching the boys (no mean feat, and one that Thai Navy Seals couldn't do), and returning successfully, Viggo's character Rick ("I don't even like kids") comes up with a cra-cra plan involving their mutual friend, Dr. Harris (Edgerton) and I won't spoil what the plan is, but we all know that-incredibly-it worked! If this already lengthy film had featured detailed backgrounds on the rescuees, as well, it would be a potential 10/10, but admittedly too long. Hence I give it a strong 8/10 and recommend it!

Thank god we knew the outcome otherwise the suspense would have been unbearable. Even so it had us gripped from start to finish. Gritty accurate portrayal of a real life incident that we all watched unfurl on our news apps with baited breath. At the time I cried when the boys were found and again when they were rescued, now I know the true extent of the rescue I feel it even more incredible.

Over the last 10 - 15 years the career of beloved TV actor turned Academy Award winning director Ron Howard has turned more and more into a workmanlike loop, one that sees the talented if often uninspiring talent either bait Oscar voters with surefire award hits or direct mindless blockbuster's designed purely for mass entertainment and nothing else.Leaning towards his former staple, the based on the true story Thirteen Lives is the usual type of Howard film that would've in times past shown up in limited showings around the Xmas period with hope of making its way into some Top 10 of the year lists and snaring a few cheeky award nominations but after falling victim to the recent MGM aquirement that has seen much of its line up of films be shunned too direct to streaming offerings, Thirteen Lives is unlikely to make much of a mark despite its innoffensive treatment of a miraculous true story that is far more engaging than this effort.Facing another hurdle in the fact just mere months ago in 2021 the BAFTA nominated The Rescue came out, a documentary that mixed real life footage with carefully recreated reinactments of this incident, for anyone that has watched that film or carefully studied the story of 13 Thailand souls trapped in a deadly underground cave system, Howard's effort here suffers badly from what has come before it and while it's precision to accuracy can be applauded, when weighed up against The Rescue it pales in comparion in the tension and character building stakes.Nabbing an all-star cast to bring proceedings some extra prestige, Howard's actors all deliver typically solid turns, with it particulary good to once more see Viggo Mortensen in a Hollywood leading role and Colin Farrell and Joel Edgerton doing well in their turns as the trio bring the real life heroes of Rick Stanton, John Volanthen and Harry Harris to life but with a lack of development or background exploration of these amazing true figures halting the emotional enagement levels of Thirteen Lives in its tracks, even if there's no doubt many viewers will be kept on tenterhooks in the films trial against the odds final act.Much like he has done with recent efforts like In the Heart of the Sea, Solo: A Star Wars Story and Hillbilly Elergy, Howard directs Thirteen Lives like you would expect someone to do sticking very closely to the Hollywood rulebook 101, there's little surprise with his decisions, little flair with how things are shot and there being a feeling that while perfectly watchable and no doubt effective in certain circles, Thirteen Lives is another Howard film that is happy in its generic self at all times and for a story like this, one would've hoped for a little more imagaination and heart.Final Say -Unlikely to make much of a dent in any signifcantly impactful way, Thirteen Lives is another mildly entertaining Ron Howard drama that is unable to better its preceeding documentary counterpart and becomes a film that misses a chance to turn a miraculous true story into a similary special viewing experience.3 Spongebob Squarepants cakes out of 5Jordan and Eddie (The Movie Guys)

Having lived through the heart breaking reality in 2018, was intrigued to see this movie and how it would be dealt with. A no nonsense, no scenes looking for effect, no goodies or baddies, just a tense and intriguing film. The rescues were amazing, what they had to do to save those boys. A well constructed respectful film, highly recommended. Claustrophobic and the maps gave you some idea of how long each dive was. Only thing not sure about is Colin Farrel' English accent! During the reality of 2918, no information about the water engineer that I remember, and what he did with the sink holes, amazing!

Highly recommend. I like the approach taken to film this. It's low key and no Hollywood nonsense. Yet it's suspenseful, gripping, emotional and does not dramatize. Its 2.5 hrs long but it does not drag for one moment and immediately goes into the story and shows u the sacrifices made to rescue the children and coach. I agree with what some of the reviewers say that there's no focus on the background of the children. Actually the viewers have more information on the foreign rescuers than on those being rescued. I guess that's one fault there in this movie. But I do appreciate that the movie does show a bit of culture and lifestyle of the locals. In any case, the length of the movie is already about 2.5 hours.

reviews.review_title: Watch The Rescue to get the real story, this feels cheap
reviews.content: I was so looking forward to this.I have read Dr Harris's book and watched The Rescue 3 times because this story inspires me so much. That humans can do great things when they work together.But this felt cheap and it felt like it was leaving out all the other amazing divers involved in the rescue.Leaving out Harry's diving partner Craig felt wrong and the way they made it seem like they approved the whole thing quickly was a joke. Harry and Craig could have gone to Thai prison for taking the risks they did and Harry could have lost his licence. They just washed over all that like it was easy.On the flip side there were parts in this that were beautifully done and moments where Ron Howard captured the humanity of this event and how department and terrifying the situation was for all involved. Moments that moved me to tears.So still we'll worth watching but I highly recommend watching The National Geographic's The Rescue on Disney Plus to get a better understanding of what really went down. Then you will really appreciate what they actually achieved in spite of everything against them.

reviews.review_title: Great movie based on real facts
reviews.content: I think that most of the world would remember this incident as it captured everybody's heart, and for all 13 children to be taken out the cave was not a miracle but amazing teamwork by the divers. All the divers had their particular skills but none more than Richard (Harry) Harris to do what he did to the children. I was a bit surprised that his dive buddy and fellow Australian Craig Challen (jointly awarded the 2019 Australian of the year) was not mentioned in the movie. There could be a reason for this but could not find it. As a fellow diver I was very surprised to see that none of the divers wore gloves which is why their hands were all cut up. There is a reason divers wear gloves especially in confined places like cave diving. All in all it was a great movie and brought back great memories of how I felt when all 13 soccer players came out alive.

Thirteen Lives is yet another film from Ron Howard about an actual rescue mission that also happens to feature the number 13 and is executed well too. He does a strong job of recreating the situation and placing you in it. The movie itself is no small feat production wise.Running roughly two and a half hours the film is long but you don't really feel the length as it remains intresting though the last five to ten minutes start to wobble.Since it happened to take place in Thailand a good portion of the movie is in the native language which is a set back for all those who don't speak Thai; it's always better to hear a movie than read it. To attain full accuracy it is necessary but the film doesn't make any attempt to minimize it.The mission itself was a collective effort so while it focuses more on Viggo Mortensen's and Colin Farrell's characters they sort of get lost in the crowd and while they deliver convincing performances, they aren't the center of your attention. I doubt this will get Mortensen the Oscar he's deserved for so long.

reviews.review_title: Slow start of the movie, but a suspenseful final.
reviews.content: Skip the first hour. The last hour is okay. BUT the National Geographic documentary called "The Rescue" is much better.The bad: this movie has a running time of 2 and a half hours and it lasts too long at the start, with lots of talking scenes with unknown actors, that arent very thrilling. A bit tedious start. The famous English speaking actors like Viggo Mortenssen etc only enter the story after an entire hour.The good: the final rescue attempt with the famous English speaking actors during the last hour is quite suspenseful, with impressive, claustrophobic photography scenes in which the divers had to maneuver.Conclusion: a bit slowmoving (bordering on tedious) drama, but the final is suspenseful to watch.

I really can't believe this actually happened, every element of this story seems completely made up which makes the true story so much more scary. Great camera work and pretty good acting. I thought the story was very well paced and skipped the repetitive scenes which helped a lot. My one complaint would be that even though the kids are the center of the story, the divers seemed to have all the attention. They are heroes don't get me wrong, but I found it hard to sympathize with the kids or their families because of how much the movie focused on the divers.

No overdramatising here.Great acting! And yet, despite 3 a-list actors I also wouldn't say they carried the film. It was very much a shared film between the well known and not well known. Which was great.At least a third was in original Thai language so this added authenticity.Very little composed music, which is good because you're not relying on added drama.As I understand, this story, unlike many 'true stories' is closely accurate to actual events. It was tense and not at all boring. Very unpretentious. It would have been nice to have seen more of the other aspects of the rescue, such as the 'water guy' and his role. And yet the film was already 2.5hrs long and it didn't feel dragged.The dynamics between the actors was great. Very unpretentious. No unnecessary frills. The actors did their own stunts and it paid off because the reality of the situation the film was portraying was brought to life.My singular criticism is that Viggo Mortensen's English accent sounded at times more African. But I forgive him because I love him.

reviews.review_title: Nail biting even if you know the ending
reviews.content: The movie did an excellent job of portraying the difficulty, as well as the physical and emotional toll of the people involved. Great writing, acting, directing and camerawork. Time-wise it was long but it wasn't like there was much that could be left out.

Felt it tried to cover little bits of everything. Sometimes in a big story there are lots of smaller stories. I felt there ought to have been focus on how the boys survived or the relationships with the divers. To me the characters felt 1 dimensional. The Documentary on the Disney Channel I think tells the whole story far better.

reviews.review_title: Thirteen Lives is interesting for viewers with little to no knowledge of what happened.
reviews.content: If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free thoughts, please follow my blog :)"Thirteen Lives follows the usual formulas of works based on true events, but Ron Howard's honest, non-Hollywoodized direction allows him to efficiently tell one of the most remarkable survival stories of the last decade.The entire cast is extraordinary, but it's Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell who mainly guide the film through all the relevant, claustrophobic plot points in a somewhat heavy viewing runtime-wise. Interesting for viewers with little to no knowledge of what happened, but the question remains as to whether it adds anything truly significant to the documentary The Rescue about the same 18 days of suffering, anxiety, and uncertainty.Massive praise for the worthy amount of screentime of the Thai language."Rating: B-

reviews.review_title: Thorough but sadly underwhelming true life drama
reviews.content: STAR RATING: ***** Brilliant **** Very Good *** Okay ** Poor * AwfulIn June 2018, young Thai football team The Wild Boars celebrate after a victory, and find themselves wondering in to the Tham Luang cave, which is exposed and open to the elements. Before long, the heavy rains have trapped the boys inside, and an alert to their disappearance is raised when they fail to turn up to a party organised by their parents. A massive rescue operation, on a worldwide scale, is launched to save them, and renowned divers Jack Valanthan (Colin Farrell) and Rick Stanton (Viggo Mortensen) lead the mission, but when their efforts come under strain, an unconventional method is used to ensure the boys rescue.Real life can often be looked on to form the most stirring drama, more affecting than any Hollywood screenwriter could manage, especially given the real world outcomes attached to it, which will provoke more natural human reactions. Thirteen Lives brings to the screen a soberingly recent real life event, that will still be powerfully fresh in peoples minds, and so potentially more impactful. With two A list stars in the lead, and decorated director Ron Howard at the helm, the stage is set for a dynamic, charged production. But while Thirteen Lives is not without its merits, sadly it can't be said to be totally the sum of its parts.Even if the story overshadows the star power, it can still be said that the pairing of Farrell and Mortensen is a mouth-watering prospect that promises some raw dynamism, but somehow here, even with true life stakes attached to their deeds, they fail to truly generate the spark that their ability could muster, even if they are individually believable and convincing (even with Farrell's off-putting British accent.) As events progress, and the story goes on, it does create an authentic sense of realism, without any Hollywood theatrics and sensationalism, which is to its credit. However, no matter how in depth it is, the concluding impression is just the feeling of a glorified movie of the week, somewhat overlong and over-indulgent to further add to the problems.There's nothing more uplifting (in the heart and mind, anyway) than a true life tale with a happy ending, and there's definitely some good stuff to unwrap here. There's just too much going on, and not enough to really hit your taste buds. ***

The 2018 Tham Luang Cave Rescue was an incredible feat of courage & resilience, seen across the world - so a movie was bound to happen. 'Thirteen Lives' is that with Ron Howard at the helm and Viggo Mortensen, Colin Farrell & Joel Edgerton taking the key roles.So it seems odd that the result was so mediocre. There are pacing issues, the characters are all at odds and unlikable (why would you be a firefighter, cave rescue diver if you had such disdain for others?) not to mention the ropey accents from Viggo & Colin.This is then juxtaposed against how this achievement was about people from across the globe coming together and working for a greater good. And maybe that was the reality, but from a viewers point of view it just diverted the attention away from its purpose; and over a 2 1/2 hour period made it feel more like a B Movie experience rather than a showcase of this amazing feat.
This was maybe the best movie I've watched this year. Don't miss it! It's just phenomenal and I couldn't stop crying, so many heartbreaking scenes. It's an instant classic.

reviews.review_title: Thank you Ron Howard. Great movie
reviews.content: Well done true story. You can't take your eyes away from it. Made me cry and smile. I highly recommend this movie.it's a must watch ! Very intense. Keeps you on the edge of your seat.

One of the best movies for a while. Incredible story, incredibly well filmed, flawless acting.Colin Farrells British accent was 100%...no surprises Viggos accent is spot on, he's amazing in everything he does.

I was convinced that this was a B Rated movie directed by a budget Director. The development, script, creativity and overall general execution was more like a film for TV. Then I found out it was Ron Howard. WTF!?A very generic film. Starts way too fast. Felt cheap and nasty. Had some awful accents. Literally zero character development and just a script by numbers. Boys trapped, rescue, done. The lack of imagination was terrible. Zero creativity or attempt to focus in. The film was just doing too much, too fast, too badly.With one exception. The claustrophobia. The narrowness and danger. It was occasionally very effective. But this was in short supply.This event deserved better. The people involved deserved better. Whilst it was acceptable as a reenactment documentary, it was very poor as a dramatic film. Ron Howard!? WTF!

reviews.review_title: Great film if you haven't watched the documentary
reviews.content: This is a great film depicting what these specialist cave divers and the Thai boys soccer ball team had endured throughout historic natural disaster. It brings the story to life without mega effects and without adding in anything to over dramatise what really happened. You follow the divers journey with some first person views of the treacherous challenges needed to overcome getting through this cave. The visuals are amazing so much so that I watched this with someone who is claustrophobic and they were clenching in their seat throughout. A really good cast to do this story justice.The only issue I have is that I watched the documentary (The Rescue) first; I may be biased because of this. There were so many details left out in the film which left some gaps of questions that the documentary covers.If you have watched the film first please watch the documentary and think for yourself.

I remember this rescue as if it was yesterday. I think it's amazing what Ron Howard and all of the cast and crew did to condense almost a month into a two hour show. Excellent work. Perfect casting, especially the Thai casting. IMHO I don't think it could've been any better than it was. Kudos to everyone involved.

reviews.review_title: Forgoes White Saviour Narratives For Something More Truthful
reviews.content: I am not fair on Ron Howard - not that he would care the slightest bit for my opinion. I have him filed away in my mind as a safe pair of hands, a bit dull and prone to sentimentality. Sometimes true - but by no means always. I feared a film like this, telling a genuinely remarkable true story which we all know - would play to the worst of those. The reverse is true. It brings out the best in Howard and those around him; it's understated in the best ways, there's a lack of sentimentality which makes it all the more moving, and it's success stems at least in part from an unpredictable creative decision which pays off well. Movies about disasters like to - need to, in fact - lay on a spectacular disaster. This doesn't show us any of that - perhaps because the involvement of children might have made it somehow exploitative - and instead focuses on the widespread relief effort and the emotional toll on those involved. Most impressively it eschews a classic trap of these films - there is not a hint of the white saviour about all this. The breadth of those involved is always well portrayed, and no one person is in charge or more heroic than anyone else. Local customs, rituals and religion are to the fore. It packs a subtly powerful emotional punch, and it speaks to something deeper by choosing a path less often trod by these sorts of films.

reviews.review_title: Expected more depth , ironic isn't it?
reviews.content: Heavy story, hard to imagine what all of them had felt. It needed a different approach, felt too detailed for a movie, almost a documentary, and it was too rushed and problem solving, dry, monotone, without any sound or music that made you feel the rush, emotions, the climax of the movie in order to feel like you're watching a artistic movie. As a conclusion, here for the cast and a bit for the rating, stayed for the cast, but that's it. Admirable efforts, it's a pity some of us only on this day found out about that event. There is still hope for humanity though. We need more stories like these, better told. Thank you! Peace and Love!

A disturbing film, about the huge effort made by some people and the risks they took to save children from certain death.A film that keeps you in suspense from the beginning to the end, a bright film that shows that we humans are capable of great things.There are so many moments of maximum tension, there are so many emotional moments to the point of tears, there are so many unforeseen situations, and the solution by which the children were saved is brilliant.The main actors are first class and play impeccably, but also the rest of the mostly Asian actors play extremely convincingly so that you get the feeling that everything is real.No one should miss such a movie.

Based on the true events of thailand rescue mission, the movie mainly works because of the plot explaining the phases of rescuing. Though it was easy to capture the stranded kids inside the cave. When the 1st card comes that it took nearly 6hrs to reach the kids place., I got shocked.The movie runs over 2hr 30mins, but it's worth of every minute to spend. It was a passing news when it happened., seeing the struggle and determination to help the kids is really applaudable. Kudos the creators and the people who made this as a film.

Yes this is technically incredibly well done, capturing the details of this incredible rescue.But we all know the end result, so there really is no tension. We know the kids get out.The details were fascinating, but this might as well been a documentary for the complete lack of emotion on the screen.

This is one of Viggo and Colin's best performances. This movie is an epic retelling of a story that shows grit and strength to push through and be heroes at a level that has never been accomplished before. Ron Howard directs this exhilarating ride into a terrifying reality that twelve young boys and their coach faced for over two grueling weeks. This movie is one of the best films of the year, and based off a true story that is unforgettable.

reviews.review_title: One of Ron's Best Movies in Years
reviews.content: To start off right away, the cinematography and sound design are the stand outs in the film, making this an immersive storytelling experience. It's shot in a way where it almost feels like a documentary. When the divers traverse through the cave system, the sound is distinct and heightens the tension which gets complimented by its score. The actors all play their part well, nothing dramatic, they keep it to a minimum, but it helps with the realism. It also does a good job at highlighting the efforts made by the people on the outside while our main characters make their way through the flooded tunnels of the cave. The way that Ron Howard decided to direct and tell this real life story makes this a worthwhile experience and one of his best movies. Final verdict: 9/10.

I can't judge the film. There isn't unwanted drama, there isn't wastage of script, there isn't any actor who is there for no reason or doesn't contribute to the story, the parents are shown only when needed. This is wonderful writing. I don't know the exact account of the incident but this film made me cry though it had very less scenes that would make one cry. I did watch Ron Howard explaining the scenes on a YouTube video and it's just fantastic. Oh, the scene when we first see the boys in the cave made me go numb with tears. Beautifully done. As usual take a bow Mr. Ron Howard!

This is the Hollywood version of events and is the second movie based on the Thailand cave rescue in 2018. The first movie, The Cave was a Thai production and was released in 2019. The Thai version featured some of the actual people who were there including foreign divers and local Thais. This version features big name Hollywood actors. I'll leave it up to you to decide which is the more accurate account. There's also a documentary which I haven't seen.The main difference is the treatment of Vernon Unsworth, the British cave diver who co-ordinated the rescue attempt. In the 2019 Thai version, Vernon is treated as a central character and is given the respect he deserves. In the Hollywood version, Vernon is a peripheral character and is even derided by the other divers. Given Vernon was honored by both the Thai and British Crown for his efforts and this movie is an insult to him.Neither the Thai nor Hollywood version mention a certain African American billionaire and IMDB don't want him mentioned either, so I won't.

reviews.review_title: Poor execution of an incredible event
reviews.content: I've seen the original documentary featuring the real people involved in this rescue and I must say that this movie did an amazing work replicating the scenes but what I find very disappointing is how fast paced the whole movie was. There was no background story on any of the divers, nor the kids. And the continuity was so bad. They just keep jumping around from one scene to the next without any thought or explanation. Also I don't want to say the actors were very cold, emotionless and that made their acting very bland but I guess they were just trying to be as accurate as the real divers. I think they could have done a bit more to add flesh to the whole story but all in all it was a good attempt.

I've watched the Documentary "The Rescue", and in this film we get even more details on how the events unfold. Definitely know it wasn't an easy task to take them out but wow.. this film really shows some of the perils and decision making that happened.

4 out of 5 stars.Thirteen Lives is a good biographical survival film based on the Tham Luang cave rescue when a group of young kids and there coach got stuck in the cave. When the cave started flooding in from the heavy rain. And a few experienced cave divers are at a race against time to figure out a way to get the kids out.Good plot. Ron Howards direction is good. Showing a rescue team on a desperate search on trying to rescue the kids. Before they lose the air in the caves or starvation. The script did not focus on the kids as much when they were stuck in the caves. Or there struggle on trying to dig there way out which was briefly discussed. The film does show the rescue teams desperate search for solutions on getting into the cave and out with the kids safely.Colin Farrell, Viggo Mortensen, and Joel Edgerton all did great with their roles. The film does get a bit of a thrill and suspense during the rescue mission. It definitely is one of those strong powerful films about survival.
Great acting, very well done. It held my attention every single step of the way...Hats off to all involved because they truly did this harrowing, yet hopeful story justice.
Simply brilliant. Gripping and brilliant. I remember following this on the news at the time but had no idea as to the complexity of the rescue. Fantastic.

Had this been a script, the movie wouldn't have been believable. The fact that it is a real story and you know how it is going to end makes this movie even more stressful because you tell yourself "there is no way this is real". But amazingly it is, and big kudos to everyone involved. Awesome and must see.

reviews.review_title: Nothing Short of an Amazing Movie
reviews.content: Don't let the English Subtitles in the beginning turn you away from this movie. When the international team shows up, there is plenty of English. Vito Mortensen and Colin Farrell both brought intense emotion to this true story. Ron Howard hit's another home run with this movie. You know what will happen in the end from the news reports that were reported around the world, but watching how the rescue unfolded and happened is truly an amazing story. Cave Diving is dangerous, but this movie shows how serious it really is and how taxing on the body and mind it can be, especially doing a rescue of 13 young boys and a coach who kept them alive while waiting. Nice tribute in the end to the two Thai Special Forces Divers who died because of this rescue. An amazing movie.

reviews.review_title: Great Movie, thrilling without being exploitive
reviews.content: I saw this on Prime. I wanted to see it in a theater but it did not play near me. Ron Howard always puts together a great film, and this is no different. The cast was brilliant. I can't say enough about Viggo Mortensen's portrayal of Rick Stanton. The accent, the surly attitude and the mannerisms were spot on. And all the actors did their own diving. The diving scenes are not repetitive because each time they show a new challenge or outcome. It was really a story about how 5 nerdy English cave divers risked their lives to save these kids. The Thai Seals were not cave divers, but did support work and the many Thai people outside the cave helped as well, even flooding their own rice fields to help the boys. It was a miraculous outcome for the boys. At the end you realize the emotional toll this took on everyone involved.

Some years back few boys and their coach were trapped in Thailand cave and rescued them by professional divers...
Really I was read on newspaper and watch news jn channels but really got to know the hardest parts of the rescue operation..
Really mind blowing Making and all are acted soo well..
After movie starts at 5th minute boys got trapped in cave later the whole movie showd the rescue operation..
Must watch rescue thriller..!

reviews.review_title: Another excellent film by Ron Howard
reviews.content: Highly recommend. Will not compare this film to the documentary - it stands alone quite well. A film that highlights one of the most dangerous activities on earth - cave diving rescue. Don't believe there's been another film quite like this with the subject at hand. The script was very well written. Excellent photography. Actors performances were outstanding - even the Thai actors performed very well.. This film could have been 3 times longer if it described the back stories of all the activities and characters - it stuck to the basic format of the story, which had enough drama to make this an outstanding creation. A film that pretty much anyone can enjoy, only a very small amount of obscene language. Watched this at home - but it would have been an outstanding film to see in the theater.

With all the sht that is going on in the world today its so nice to look back only 4 years ago when 5000 people from 17 different countries came together to save the lives of these boys, while risking their own. Well told story of true bravery.

reviews.review_title: Remember when a Billionaire tried to Hijack and take Credit for this rescue?
reviews.content: This film is a magnificently executed adaptation of a real-world rescue which attracted international attention. It is a testament to humility, perseverance and cooperation.I am an open water diver, and find cave diving terrifying. I cannot begin to wrap my head around the complexity of a cave rescue. The bravery of all those involved in saving these Thai children is laudable and faithfully represented by Ron Howard. Darkness, strong currents, falling rocks, tight cave entrances and an almost 3k of passages underwater presented a daunting challenge to the international team of volunteers who risked their own lives to rescue the stranded children. Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell lend their undeniable talent to this understated gem. The director also makes a conscious effort to respectfully portray the vitality of the Thai people's faith, the sacrifices made by their farmers, and the resolve shown by youths who faced death as a team.With time running out for those trapped, it is important to remember that "real-life's tony stark" and the world's wealthiest man sought to capitalize on the relief effort, sending a Submarine which he reminded the world was developed by engineers at SpaceX. Upon being rejected, King Twit launched an unhinged attack on one of the divers who helped coordinate the rescue. I hope one day he will stoop to watching this movie.

I love the Marvel and DC movies. The Avengers, Justice League and all of those amazing spectaculars. However, the people who put their lives on the line to rescue the children from the caves in Thailand...I am an ex-firefighter and I salute them, the best of humanity. Swimming through 4km of underground flooded caves to rescue someone you don't even know. Real superheroes!What an amazing dramatisation of a real life event. Thank you.
Fantastic movie about unbelievable heroes and incredible resilience of the children and coach. Really enjoyed this movie and all the actors did a great job. Loved it and highly recommend.

This incredible true - tear jerking - film is gripping as well as the roller coaster it must have been in real life.All hail to all of the rescuers and the bravery of the young boys themselves who triumphed against the most unbelievable odds.Excellent to everyone involved in the making od the film but more importantly to those who were involved in real life.

This one should not work anywhere near as well as it does. The vast majority of us will be very familiar with the story (unless you have been leaving in a cave - shocking pun intended) including the ending. Its 2 and hours long and essentially shot in a single location where a rescue team initially locate and then extract a group of stranded young children from a flooded cave. The story is remarkable and touching but in the wrong hands it could have been so ordinary - Mr Howard is becoming a master of his craft. A big shout out to all the actors, wonderful casting and perfect performances from all. First class film.

Very interesting interpretation based on an unfortunate accident that luckily had a good outcome. The tension and claustrophobia of the general situation is effectively represented, added to the high emotionality, but without falling into exaggerations, which is greatly appreciated, since the final product looks quite realistic.In the first act of the film there are events that happen too quickly, there are time jumps that are too marked, which hinders the flow of the rest of the story a bit. There are also a couple of elements that perhaps could have been left out to make a shorter movie. But overall it's a good film. It comes from a great filmmaker, so there are no major objections in any aspect.Although it doesn't stand out, it's correct, it's intriguing, it's realistic.Recommended for those who like this type of cinematographic representations.

It rare i give a 10/10 but this film was amazing
Ron Howard's is a good director i really only put this film on as there wasd nothing on and was looking for something to fill 1hr while i eat tea and thinking i was not going to enjoy it thinking i had seen it all on the news it would give me time to fill and enough time for me to relise this film was rubbishso i actually watched expexting disapointment the first 15 mins was a bit annoying as it was subtitled which was leading to think i going to turn this off in a mini am glad i didnt there was things in it i did not even know like the kids was drugged with 3 different drugs and even had to google it thinking this cant be true and a few other facts and must admit i cried quite a few times though out the film this is the first time i watched a film expexting rubbish for it to turn me aroundignore the stupid 1 stars these are from people who probably cant read or have the expansion span to concertrate on subs for 20 mins and watch at the same time and ignore the consperercicy idiots saying it was all lies these people wear tin hats and think everything on tictoc is real because its not in the main stream news.

I'm sure that ron howard, amazon and hollywood only made this movie to mess with my head. Make me think, where have I heard this story before. Is this the same movie I saw last year. Well, no it's not. There's been two recent movies just before this so if it's not to mess with me, then why? Why waste a lot of money and talent to make a movie that has already been told, and much better, btw. Also, there's enough similarities between the natgeo movie and this one to scream plagiarism. Technically I'm sure this was difficult to make, expensive, and the production value is somewhat good. But, the cinematography, casting, costume design, all pretty low brow. The worst part is how they make the thai people look stupid and over governed with useless bureaucrats. A typically american perspective even when the heros are brits and aussies. The whole production team, including howard, should be banned from thailand forever. But the worst crime is that it's just not very entertaining. Maybe it would have been better if howard made it as a documentary.

Very visceral & immersive. It's intense but doesn't loose its heart. It's presented clearly & easy to understand with some gritty yet beautiful camerawork. The tone doesn't progress but the actors channel emotion..
..
Very visceral & immersive. It's intense but doesn't loose its heart. It's presented clearly & easy to understand with some gritty yet beautiful camerawork. The tone doesn't progress but the actors channel emotion..
..
Very visceral & immersive. It's intense but doesn't loose its heart. It's presented clearly & easy to understand with some gritty yet beautiful camerawork. The tone doesn't progress but the actors channel emotion.

The acting in this movie is so wooden by everyone involved, Thai, British, American, Australian, et al, you'd think that the boys could've just floated out of the cave. Much of the action of the movie takes place in extremely cramped cave passages and underwater and it's almost impossible to figure out who is who and after you've seen one "swim through the tunnel" scene you've seen them all. The Thai actors are given relatively little to do. I don't know much about the real story other than what I saw on the news but I would've thought there's be a big "woke" protest about the movie, depicting the Asian Thai characters in too deep and needing the clever, much more talented white guys to come rescue them. The movie was too long by a half hour.

reviews.review_title: Should have been so much better!
reviews.content: What's the point of this direct-to-stream movie?We all know what happened, so instead of giving us some sort of documentary using famous Hollywood actors, why not give us something to be a little surprised about? To keep us engaged by following traditonal screenwriting rules?When basing a movie on a true event you are allowed some creative freedom, and creative freedom is usually needed for the movie not to become boring and repetitive, which is the case here. There's no drama between any of the characters for example. The whole movie is pure information sharing and the leads diving back and forth with very little tension involved. What a waste of acting talent.Ron Howard, who is a couple of decades past his prime, could have used a "ticking clock" - the 2nd monsoon approaching fast, which would build tension, but decided to play it very safe, like he usually does. He must be the least controversial director in Hollywood.There are so many opportunities here that are not exploited but should be. The grieving families that grow more or more desperate as days go by, the fear from some of the divers etc. We are shown almost none of that.'Thirteen Lives" could have been great if helmed by a director who dared to take some chances.

Nothing more valuable in life that to cherish life itself.. If Hollywood and all movie making is about this value, maybe life would've vee better.. My sincere gratitudes to all cast, stars and crew for this great work.. Very much uplifting and gorgeous.There are genuine stunts makers and heros around the world.. True stories NOT fake.. They deserve all respect and acknowledgement for their work and concern.. Their targets is to save lives even if risking their own.. No fake intentions or selfish interests.. Humans in their pure and ultimate form.. No boundaries and no alien agenda... Can we make more of this work to bring people together..Selection of the stars (the divers) can't be any better.. They are humans, sensitive and tough men.. Just loveable.. The world is very much vulnerable and not in its best shape.. Story writers.. Please.

Thirteen Lives.A rescue mission of twelve young boys and their coach after being trapped in an underground cave in Thailand that is flooding. Based on actual events .I believe that I had the best possible experience watching this movie because I didn't know a thing about what happened in Thailand and I didn't know how things went .It was thrilling and breathtaking with all those fabulous diving scenes , I really enjoyed it and I felt every moment of it , situations like this requires a lot of sacrifices and solidarity ,the things that were offered by the people from different countries ,this is what we call humanity ,risking your life for others lives and nothing more!What wasn't expected is the film's structure ,It didn't add much to the story and it delivered it as it is ,the thing that a documentary movie can do it even better .They tried to force a dramatic perspective in it but It just didn't work .All those names in the cast !Colin Farrell ,Viggo Mortensen and Joel Edgerton . All of them to make diving scenes ! I can't believe this.But it always good to see these top class actors and I really enjoyed there presence .Ron Howard in the directing too...
It was promising and it didn't disappoint but it could have been better .

reviews.review_title: Hit me right in the feels
reviews.content: Rarely have i been at the edge of my seat - for a movie i already know how is going to end.I absolutely loved this movie.Brilliant acting all around.Beautifully made.

reviews.review_title: Excellent docudrama with director Ron Howard at his best. On Amazon Prime.
reviews.content: Barely four years have passed since one of history's most astonishing rescues. In Thailand, twelve young soccer players and their coach were trapped in a cave system being relentlessly flooded in pre-monsoon rains. Volunteers from Chiang Rai Province and the world gathered to help for 18 hopeless days.Fortunately for that world and the team caught in the cave, retired firefighter Richard Stanton (Viggo Mortensen), tech consultant John Volanthen (Colin Farrell), and Dr. Harry Harris (Joel Edgerton) came to help and ultimately provide the solution to saving the doomed boys. Director Ron Howard, who knows something about tight spots and its heroes (see Apollo 13) and writer William Nicholson (see Everest) have crafted a clear story of heroism and cool in the face of death.Howard, leagues away from his disappointing Hillbilly Elegy, doesn't clutter the narrative with choking emotionalism but rather elects to tell the linear story including parents, local authorities, and divers with spare back story but minute by minute tension as the days tick off and the solution remains elusive.It's only a short film time until the boys are located but seeming centuries until the two Brits come upon the answer, which is as fraught as any fictionalized drama ever seen on the screen.Nature with its indomitable rains seems the likely winner when combating frail humanity; in true Howard style and the best of humanity, only one life will be lost, that of former Thai Navy Seal Saman Kunan, dying of asphyxiation after he delivered diving cylinders to the team.Thirteen Lives is a splendid version of a reality that seems unreal (see the competent documentary, The Rescue). During a time when we have lost confidence in our selves and our leaders combatting a scurrilous pandemic, it is heartening to see real selflessness in the face of tragedy and Nature once again challenging us to be more than we thought we could be.

reviews.review_title: A Gripping Dramatisation Of An Incredible True Story
reviews.content: A constantly riveting & consistently thrilling dramatisation of the Tham Luang cave rescue effort that saw the best of humanity join hands & work together to save 13 people trapped deep within the flooded cave, Thirteen Lives is neat, straightforward & uncomplicated and delivers the thrills without deviating much from the true story to succeed as a gripping survival offering.Directed by Ron Howard (A Beautiful Mind & Rush), the film picks up momentum relatively quick with its swift setup & early establishment of the stakes at play and keeps the tension alive at all times by letting the elements deepen the peril. The scenes within the cave brim with suffocation & claustrophobia while the media circus on the outside brings a chaotic energy of its own.What stands out about Howard's direction is his documentary-like approach as he keeps things grounded and doesn't attempt to dilute the real-life incident with fabricated scenes to make the journey more cinematic or have the story be all about one character's heroics. Viggo Mortensen, Colin Farrell & Joel Edgerton play their unassuming roles with an understated touch and it works in the film's favour.Overall, Thirteen Lives is clean & clinical filmmaking that may not offer a full-fledged account of the rescue operation but skims through enough detail to keep the viewers' interest & investment sustained in the proceedings. While its 147 mins runtime is a tad excessive, the steady pacing & kinetic treatment helps keep the complaints at bay. Crafted with finesse & packed with emotion, Ron Howard's latest is worth a shot.

Regardless of the topic, this film is a disaster .Not a single thing makes it worth watching, it's just too poorly done in every respect, in every department .The movie is not only technically inept, it never is involving .And that is already too many words and too much time spend commenting on this amateur drivel .

reviews.review_title: Very good movie about real events
reviews.content: Greetings from Lithuania.Thirteen Lives (2022) is a very good movie telling a very true story. It's based on the event most of us saw back in 2018 and were holding our breaths. Directing of this movie was superb as for a running time 2 h 30 min this movie was always involving to watch. Also the story itself about those heroes who risked their lives in order to save boys was incredible. I didn't know how exactly the itself was made therefore the story was very engaging. Regarding acting - it was superb but you expect nothing else from cast like Vigo Mortensen in a first place.Overall, this is a very good movie telling a very real story. Very engaging and moving this a must watch.

Great cast, excellent performance, beautiful story of people coming together for the sake of humanity. There was a few scenes at the beginning that happen a bit too quick and more depth with his the boys kept their sanity would have been perfect.

I really liked the movie! From the first minutes the situation was brewing, without taking away the viewer's time for unnecessary details. Perfect ! The game of actors, American and Thai, everything turned out harmoniously without unnecessary emotionality, but at the same time touching and sincere! I think this is how a documentary should be!I cried .. I think the script that brings you to tears is a good script also the acting, you can't do without it! I chewed a lot, whether the doctor's method, with the help of anesthesia, would work to save the children .. I thought, what would I do in his place? ... it is difficult ! If you completely remove emotions and take risks ... well, if a person is very nervous and subject to doubts .. it would be difficult for him to do everything accurately and competently ... I admire this story! I don't know how it was in reality, but if it's exactly the same (the scenario without any changes in the real story), then great respect to the divers and just people who did everything to help and save the children.

I remember following the rescue story from our senior journalist (he is retired, so its a more of a personal blog). He wrote about it everytime there is significant progress and adding a flavour of personal touch from his point of view on every article he wrote (its kind of his specialty during his reporting time), so we as reader can also feels the emotion/ struggle of the divers/rescuer, the family and the victim. Of course, one controversy didn't insert into the movie is Elon Musk tweet about one of the diver and his offer to help using one of Tesla invention , cmiiw. The dive scenes were intense. I actually didn't even realize it was that long. There was so many people and factors that were really involved, it would have to be a mini series. I really enjoyed this one. The only thing I had an issue with was how they displayed timelines... it was very hard to follow the diving intervals and get a sense of how long the process was.

reviews.review_title: The only saving grace is Joel Edgerton
reviews.content: The National Geographic documentary, "The Rescue", is absolutely fantastic and we'll worth a watch. It captures the emotion and real life drama of the rescue as seen from many points of view. It captures the emotions of the tragic death of Saman. The true stress felt by Dr Harris.This movie is quite simply the worst movie I have ever seen from Ron Howard. I am so thoroughly disappointed.What he has failed to capture is the real life drama that unfolded. He has over dramatised some scenes and missed the boat with others.With due respect to the actors, I think they make the best of a bad lot. Joel Edgerton for one doesn't overplay his part.But, as we know, the Thai Captain in charge of the operation did not jump in the water to help the last diver out. Not was it as simple to get the Minister to give the go ahead.If this had been portrayed truly and faithfully, the stress of the divers concocting a plan while the authorities were aiming for a zero risk rescue, contemplating leaving the boys in the cave, would have been more than enough drama for the big screen.Maybe Ron has lost his touch.Nothing but respect for the divers, but it's not their job to make this into a movie - that falls to the director, writers and producers.Like I said, stick with the National Geographic documentary - a far better production in all measures.

Love Ron Howard most of the time but these is absolutely no point in making this as the real life documentary, The Rescue, is light years better.I can't fathom why they would waste millions on a project like this that already has a definitive version. Perhaps they would have been better off dramatizing the court battle involving Mr, jacka55 himself, Elon Muck !!

reviews.review_title: Thirteen Lives is an emotional story everyone needs to see
reviews.content: A lot of work went into creating the technical aspects of "Thirteen Lives," from Molly Hughes' skillful recreation of the interiors of Thailand's Tham Luang Nang Non cave to its two lead actors getting SCUBA-certified so they could dive without much use of stunt doubles. The underwater cinematography by Sayombhu Mukdeeprom is impressive and the sound mix is often quite eerie in its depiction of water and cave noises. All this effort is for naught. Ron Howard's latest directorial effort is a tedious, mediocre retelling of the June, 2018 incident where 12 Thai adolescents and their soccer coach were trapped in a flooded cave for 18 days. They were rescued by an international crew of cave divers led by Rick Stanton and John Volanthen. "Thirteen Lives," despite spending an equal amount of time watching underwater sequences in passageways so narrow that one person can barely fit through, let alone ferry another person to safety. Despite an occasional map being superimposed on the screen, viewers are barely afforded a sense of geography. Howard and his editor, James Wilcox kill the momentum and tension by often cutting between what's going on underground and the numerous attempts to divert water above. "Thirteen Lives" begins with scenes of the team practicing then riding to the cave for that poorly timed descent that coincides with the monsoon that will entrap them. In those moments, the film appears to be centering its focus on them. It's a while before we even meet any of the White actors playing the divers. And yet, the teammates are reduced to mere victims, pawns in their own story. The only parent we hear from in any regard is played by Pattrakorn Tungsupakul. As the mother of a boy named Chai, she's given very little to do besides wander around in the background praying and looking worried.

reviews.review_title: Another amazing Based on a Real life event by Ron Howard
reviews.content: A fantastic rescue movie. Very intense, amazing pacing and really good photography, specially the cave scenes. With an underwater camera amazingly well conducted. Specially for transferring the hardships of the exploring of such a unforgiven place.Although is based in a real life story, the movie manages to stay thrilling and interesting for the 150 mins. Starting for the political drama of who's in charge of the operation, the situation of the relatives to the captive soccer team and the town support to get ahead the best way possible.At this point, I can say with confidence that Ron Howard is one of the greatest modern directors.

I didn't think I was going to like this movie as much as I did but I really liked it. The coach and the kids going to the cave and getting trapped there was dumb but some people do silly things so there you have it!!! It happened in real life so I'm sure that the coach instantly regret his stupid decision once he heard the rain.

reviews.review_title: There's no .5 otherwise it would be 6.5
reviews.content: I'm always pessimistic of movies being made after actual event, bit like ambulance chasers who don't really care about the event -they're just after the $$$. Congrats to Howard beating Eastwood for movie rights. Being film by Ron I knew this film wasnt going to soar to majestic heights but due to cast I was interested. Ron just doesn't have the magic touch in directing. Story excellent. Script have to say very very average. Disappointed in viggo as he was very wooden and seem disinterested. Acting from white cast seem awkward at time. However standout was Colin. That's what I call acting. He really transformed himself into the character. Whatever the story or cast, a howard film is never going to attain magical cinematic experience.

reviews.review_title: Excellently done and directed by Ron Howard
reviews.content: Movie focuses totally about rescue mission of 13 Thai boys. We know what happened and how it ended. Howard avoids cheap tricks and onion and serves pure spectrum of how mission was assambled and how it went from divers perspective. I can say: if this wasn't based on real events, people would say that its overdone and mission itself would appear as somenthing could never happen. But stakes were high, and director shows it in great way. From technical point, movie is perfectly directed: sound, lighting, underwater footage is top notch. Locations looks like taken from real life events. I am happy this movie was made, even more that this story had happy ending, for the most part (2 of rescuers died, as we know...)I rate it 9/10.

Ron Howard's docu-drama about the 2018 Thai Cave rescue of 12 soccer kids and their coach. It's a decently well-told and very well-produced movie. The tech specs are quite good with exceptional sound design.Screenwriter William Nicholson (working with Don MacPherson) and Howard follow a pretty straightforward path. Colin Ferrell and Viggo Mortensen similarly are fairly low key even as the two major stars in the film. Good use of graphics to show where the rescuers are helps viewers keep their bearings. Still, the filmmakers do add a bit of 'Hollywood' melodrama at points and some of the suspense seems to be - if not artificial- at least prolonged.There has already been another feature and several documentaries made on the incident, and Howard and his team add little beyond being the best made of productions. The quite exemplary 2021 doc THE RESCUE had the good sense to understand where the story peaked and moved expeditiously to its conclusion, whereas Howard milks it for almost another full hour. It's not an obscure tale - it was literally the biggest news in the world only a couple of years ago.THIRTEEN LIVES is an honorable effort, if a bit superfluous.
Brilliant movie which was very accurate, with high drama and emotion. A true story that shows the perspective from all sides. Great cast and superbly shot. A must watch.

reviews.review_title: Ron Howard made Thirteen Lives accurate and thus making us feel emotionally invested, it's full of suspension and tension - My Ultimate Review
reviews.content: Thirteen Lives is based on the Tham Luang cave rescue that occurred in 2018, the film is directed and produced by Ron Howard, from a screenplay written by William Nicholson. Thirteen Lives has Viggo Mortensen, Colin Farrell, Joel Edgerton and Tom Bateman in main roles. In my opinion, Colin Farrell takes home the best performance but there's so many good acting performances in this film.A rescue mission is assembled in Thailand where a group of young boys and their soccer coach are trapped in a system of underground caves that are flooding.The film placed authenticity at the front, with the writers and director along with the producers creating something brilliant, something people who were there could only praise. Diver Rick Stanton praised the film's accuracy, saying the one cinematic change was that the cave water was muddy. The real divers had zero visibility. Actors Viggo Mortensen and Colin Farrell even did their own stunts and diving rather than doubles doing the work to make it even more immersive and accurate, they'd been training with Rick Stanton and John Volanthen. With the need and want for authenticity, to ultimately do the true events justice, the actors suffered panic attacks whilst doing the diving and also the experts assigned to supervise the filming stated this was the most potentially dangerous production they worked on. It shows and I'm glad they did it like that, as the suspension is kept throughout every single scene. The sets were built in an enormous airplane hangar-sized building using double Olympic-size tanks and long sections of tunnel which would be flooded with 20 feet of water. The cast would practice for several hours each day to work out their movements through each passage. Each successive section was more difficult to navigate, and was built while the first one was in use for filming. There are many more things that adds to the accuracy, the cast and crew cared something immensely.This sure is a movie you'll want to see in 2022 as it has some strong acting, stunning cinematography and a director who cares. Ron Howard created a great biopic and overall an incredible film with some flaws, and the grounded approach to tell the story is appreciated. I'm glad I did some research before watching the movie as I would otherwise have been quite lost, so do that before starting as you'll appreciate the film even more. Ron Howard did a great job making you feel invested and immersed in the story, reliving the events of that day. The cast did a phenomenal job at portraying the real people, it's thanks to them that I was emotionally invested in the characters and events. Thirteen Lives is truly a fine film, cinematically, a must watch.

People risk there life to save children.13 lives that serious. In the worst situation to save them.One rescue diver death on operation
Other one on blood infection after the rescue.10,000 people helping on rescue effort.More then 100 divers.100 government agencies.900 police officer.2000 soilder and numerous volenteer.10 police helicopter.7 police ambulance.700 diving cilnders and more.Billion liters of water removed from the cave to rescue the kids 3 weeks effort.Hats off the whole volenteer, soldiers brave divers, police personnel, and whole family waiting to see the love ones Alive.Humanity....

If Monsoon Season was approaching why were there no signs stating DO NOT ENTER as this cave floods during monsoon season.It's ironical that kids were even allowed to race through a cave like that with very little supervision. Entering areas which apparently had no signs, no pathways, with some water already there.We all know the outcome but having to watch it through 150 minutes was all too much. The dialogue and subtitles were most annoying, the Navy Seals ridiculous idiots.As some reviewers said it's the best movie they have ever seen on Amazon, I totally disagree as I have seen much more enjoyable productions than this.If anyone is wondering about my credentials I have worked in the entertainment industry for over 30 years and during that time have seen some of the best movies of all time. This is not one of them.

When Ron Howard gets his hands on a quality script with a hugely talented cast to support it, he doesn't go wrong. Yes, we know how the story ends, but that's irrelevant: getting to that end is what is worthy about this film and others like it. Kudos to all involved, especially the stunt men and women who made the leads seem so adept at diving. Kudos, too, for allowing the local citizenry to retain their language. And a massive kudo to the technicians who made the waterlogged cave seem not only real but genuinely frightening.Finally, kudos to Daniel Boone and Rod McQueen for providing the actors with such a riveting screenplay. I would watch this film a second time if for no other reason than to explore how these two writers went about accomplishing their goal.

Another example Englishman on vacation .Good movie , interesting story.The boys are the hero's and their coach . It's an unfortunate situation when adventure meets the unpredictable. Prayer and culture has a strong influence on survival .

reviews.review_title: How on earth did they shoot this movie
reviews.content: Content - I love how the movie incorporates all parts of the rescue efforts. The main narrative is focused on five members of cave rescuers from UK and Austrailia, but Howard also distributes time for a water technician with villagers, all coming together and sacrificing their livelihood and for Thailand Navy SEALs and a governor. Thai community and culture are dissolved in the movie, giving more realistic and genuine impression. The two parts of the story - foreign volunteers and solidarity within the community - are in such a harmony.Form - Setting, camera movement, lighting, and so on.. just everything. Every component of the film 'Thirteen Lives' works its part to take audience back to June in 2018 in front of TV waiting for an update on Tham Luang Cave rescue mission. After the movie, I searched internet to find out whether it was shot in the actual Tham Luang Cave or not. It turned out that they built the whole set of intricate structure of cave. Gosh so realistic that I almost believed that it was an actual cave. Camera movement sometimes following the diver's point of view or shaking hard going up and down from water level is spectacular. Underwater filming is difficult without a doubt. Kudos to both camera team and actors who give verisimilar and breathtaking performance even under demanding condition.Definitely Oscar-worthy!

This movie will give you chills from the beginning. Every one of these men are absolute heroes. To think this is just a fraction of what they really endured is unreal. Do not miss this movie... you owe it to the real life heroes to know what they risked.
Very very very good! I'm impressed.. very breathtaking. Two hours worthy! I will definitely be watching again. I could imagine the amount of time it took to pull this off!

reviews.review_title: If you know the real story watch it
reviews.content: Very stellar movie for sure. It's pretty much what you could have hoped for. The story is retold in a very faithful way with a big budget and top actors. No stupid fake action, no fake drama, no overblown cheering or crying. This is a historical movie that follows the basic outline of the story of the Western divers getting to Thailand and saving lives. I was very happy about how historically correct it is and didn't notice anything extra here. Though it did lack a few events I wanted included.I have watched probably 4 full documentaries on this rescue mission and read quite a bit about it too. I know there is another movie. A TV show. A ton of books and other docs and I have seen quite a few Youtube videos about it. The Rescue (2021) is in my view essential to watch before watching the movie. It's the best doc on the subject and respects all people involved. Many docs overlook the farmers or what the other crews did. This movie clearly just follows what the doc set up. And I'd say the doc is clearly better. The movie is a bit slow and misses some proper setup for more tension. For example, the lead diver had a Thai girlfriend, but she moved back to Thailand. It was one of the great personal stories in the doc as they got back together when he came to Thailand for this rescue and they looked like a happy couple in the doc. These small things make it personal. The movie mentioned a few other small family matters, but totally ignored any stories connecting the divers to Thailand. We also never once see any village or town. So it feels like a big miss culturally. But I loved how they weren't forced to speak English. The movie legit feels true to real life.Some diving sequences were not always clearly explained. We know the Navy seals were way out of their depth, but the movie only gets into it later and not fully. Some Navy seals were actually in the cave with the kids using up crucial oxygen. Which wasn't even mentioned as a point of tension. They mention the low oxygen, but not how extremely serious it was and why it got worse. And the monsoon season coming up would have killed the boys if they weren't rescued very fast. Which also was not mentioned before the very end.
